turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Sounds like a good Idea.

turns.speaker: KAGGS
turns.text: I don't know offhand what your best year's been, we can look it up. The idea is, we'll top it by fifteen percent.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: What? Me?

turns.speaker: KAGGS
turns.text: That's just the first year. If you aren't worth a lot more than that the second year, I'll kick you out. What do you say?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Well, uh... No.

turns.speaker: KAGGS
turns.text: No?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: I can't take that job! I mean, I mean, I can't take it right away. I'm still recuperating, I just dropped in to say hello, see everybody --

turns.speaker: KAGGS
turns.text: I didn't realize. Yeah, you do look a little pale. How soon will you be ready? A week?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: But you need a man right now. It wouldn't be fair to you to --

turns.speaker: KAGGS
turns.text: I take care of the being-fair-to-me department. Things've gone to hell this long, they can go a little longer.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Well...

turns.speaker: KAGGS
turns.text: See you in a week, Roy. I can call you Roy?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Oh, sure. Fine.

turns.speaker: KAGGS
turns.text: And I'm Perk. Short for Percy, I'm afraid.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Perk.

turns.speaker: KAGGS
turns.text: Good to have you back, Roy. I was just looking at --

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Mr. Kaggs, I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: KAGGS
turns.text: You're turning me down? Makes no sense, Roy.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: I guess I'm just not a leader of men.

turns.speaker: KAGGS
turns.text: Oh, come on, Roy.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: The truth is, Mr. Kaggs --

turns.speaker: KAGGS
turns.text: Perk, remember?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Okay, fine. Perk, the truth is, I like things the way they are now. Pick my own hours, have time for, uh, other activities...

turns.speaker: KAGGS
turns.text: A well-rounded life. I respect that. But it has to have a center, Roy, something you care about, something you can think about.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Maybe I'm just not ready for that yet.

turns.speaker: KAGGS
turns.text: Well, Roy, if that's the way you feel, I won't badger you.  Don't want to lose you as a salesman, too.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Oh, I'd like to stay on. Just keep everything the way it was.

turns.speaker: KAGGS
turns.text: That's what we'll do, then. But I tell you what, Roy. Before I hire anybody else, I'll ask you one last time. Fair enough?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Fair enough.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: So what's your story today?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: They twisted my arm.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Only one arm?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: They knocked out my tooth!

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Only one tooth?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Sure I am. What made you turn up, after all these years?

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: I'm working down in San Diego. Just for a few weeks.  Thought I'd drop in on my long-lost son.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Nice to see you.  What am I doing in here?

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Well... You're all right now, I guess. I have to get down to the track.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Thanks, uh, Lilly.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Don't mention it.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: I guess I owe you my life.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: You always did.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: What happened to your hand?

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Just a little accident. I went by your place, picked up your mall. Just bills, I'll take care of them.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: I can take care of my own bills, Lilly.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Whatever you say. The manager says your boss called.  Really pulled the wool over everybody's eyes, huh?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: What are you talking about? So I've got a job. So what?

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Stop kidding me! Four years in a town like Los Ang-gleez, and a peanut selling job is the best you can do? You expect me to believe that?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: It's there. The boss called, you said so yourself.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: And that dump you live in! Those clown pictures on the walls!

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: I like those.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: You do not! Roy Dillon? Cornball clown pictures? Commission salesman? It's all a front, isn't it? You're on the grift, I know you are. You're working some angle, and don't tell me you're not because I wrote the book!

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: You're one to talk. Still running playback money for the mob.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: That's me. That's who I am. You were never cut out for the rackets, Roy, and if you --

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: How come?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Not as tough as you, huh?

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: No. And you have to be.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Up to you.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: My boss is a guy named Bobo Justus, back in Baltimore. When a long shot gets too much action, I have to put money on that horse at the track, because it's the only way to get the odds down.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: The first day of the Delmar meet, there was a nag called Bluebell. I should have been on it. But that was the day after you came in here, so I stuck around to see how you were gonna be.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: That was my choice, nothing to do with you. I took a chance, and it didn't work out.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Bluebell came in?

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: I sent Bobo ten grand of my own money, like it was the winnings from my bets. I hoped that would cover me.  It didn't.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Lucky? You call that lucky?

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: He let me live. He let me be his friend.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: You don't put up with that! Nobody has to put up with that!

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: You do if you're where I am. Where you want to be. How'd you get that punch in the stomach, Roy?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: I tripped over a chair.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Get off the grift, Roy.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: You don't have the stomach for it.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: I just give you your life. What you do with it is up to you.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: That's right.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Roy! What are you doing in San Diego?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Myra and me come down to LaJolla for the weekend.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: If you come out to the track, don't know me.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: We won't hit the track. The beach. Couple a nice restaurants.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Four grand. For the hospital. Is that enough?

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Roy, I don't want money from you.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: I pay my debts.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: You do?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Expecting visitors?

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: No. That was the point.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: You ought to put a bandage on that.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: No can do. Have to dip in and out of my bag too much. Besides, it'll heal in the air.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: I thought... I was hoping we could play it straight with one another.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: I guess not. You'll be heading east from here, huh?

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: After the meet. Back to Baltimore.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Well... nice to see you again, Lilly.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: You, too, Roy.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Well, sure, Roy. You want me to drive up --? Okay, fine, come on down.  It won't be a home-cooked meal, you know.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Well, that's good news.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Going somewhere?

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Somewhere else, that's for sure.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: I just came back from Phoenix.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Oh, yeah? Is the frame holding?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Looks very solid, Lilly. Sit down. Take a minute, tell me about it.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: I've really got to --

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: You're dead, Lilly, it worked.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Not for long. Not when they do a fingerprint check.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Why should they? The cops are satisfied.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Bobo won't be. He'll spend the money to make sure.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Even so. You still got time. Relax a minute, tell me what happened. Sit down.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Myra followed you, huh?

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: She must have been the one that blew me off with Bobo. I guess to get me running. Did you tell her about my stash?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: No, you wouldn't. That's what she was after, though. But why hit on me?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: I wouldn't go in on a deal with her. She blamed you for it.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: As though you do what I say.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: That's pretty funny, all right. What happened in Phoenix?

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: I sat in there with her, I thought, what do I do now? Run and I've got Bobo and the law after me. Stay, and how do I explain?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: This way's perfect.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: It is, isn't it? And maybe it's a break for me after all. I've been wanting out of the racket for years, and now I'm out. I can make a clean start, and --

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: You've already made a start. Doesn't look that clean, though.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: I'm sorry. I hated to take your money, but --

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Don't be sorry. You're not taking it.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: I need this, Roy. I can't run without money, and if I can't run I'm dead.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: You must have some money.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Just a few bucks.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: And Myra's stuff?

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Her credit cards. How far am I gonna get with that?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Far enough. Maybe up to San Francisco. Or St. Louis, someplace new. Start over.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: At what?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: You're smart, Lilly, and you're good-looking. You won't have any trouble finding a job.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: A job? I've never had a legit job in my life!

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Well, you're gonna start, if you hope to live through this. A square job and a quiet life. You start showing up at the track or the hot spots and Bobo's boys will be all over you.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Roy, I know what to do with myself! It's a big world out there.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Not any more. Lilly, listen, I'm giving you good advice. I'm following it myself.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: I thought it over, and you were right. You wanted me out of the rackets, and now --

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Roy, that's fine, but I don't have time for this. Bobo --

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: I thought you'd be happy for me. After all, you --

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Bobo isn't after you! Bobo's after me, and he's goddamn good! But so am I. I'm a survivor, Roy. I survive.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: I know you do, so that's why --

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: And to survive, my way, I need money. Bobo knows about the stash in the car, so I didn't dare touch it, not if Lilly Dillon's dead. So that leaves this.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: You want a drink?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: I don't think so. You probably shouldn't either.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: No, but I'm goddamn thirsty. Ice water?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Yeah, sure, that sounds nice.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: I'll get it.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: You don't know what I'd do, Roy. You have no idea. To live.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Oh, you'll live, Lilly.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: I know what's bugging you, of course.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Oh? I didn't know anything was.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Oh, really? You've got a legitimate complaint, Roy, I don't deny that. I wasn't a very good mother when you were a kid.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Not very good!

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: A bad mother. By any standards. I've thought about it, you know, from your side, since then. I know just how bad I was.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: I wonder did you ever think about it from my side.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Never.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: No, I guess not. It was pretty lousy of me, I guess, to be a child at the same time you were. Not to stop being a child just because I had a child. I guess I was a real stinker not to be a grown-up when you needed a grown-up.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: What do you want me to do? Pin a halo on you? You're doing a pretty good job of that yourself.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: And making you feel bad at the same time, huh? But that's the way I am, you know, the way I've always been. Always picking on poor little Roy.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: For God's sake, Lilly!

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: I gave you your life twice. I'm asking you to give me mine once. I need the money.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: You're getting off the grift?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: That's right.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: That's good. You don't really belong on this side of the fence, you know.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: I don't?

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: If you stayed a crook, do you think you'd live to be my ripe age?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: I don't see why not.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Well, I guess I got it wrong, then. Seems to me I heard about a guy just your age that got hit so hard in the guts it almost killed him.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Well, uh...

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Sure, sure, that doesn't count. That's different.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Well, it doesn't matter, does it? I'm getting out.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: And that's why you've got to get rid of this money. If you keep it around, it'll just make you think how clever you are. It'll be a temptation to get back into the game.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Oh, that's it! You're stealing my money for my own good! How very motherly of you, Lilly.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: If I should get out of the racket, that goes double for you. That's why you've got to change your life completely, go to some town, get a square job, live like a john yourself. If you try to do it your way, what future is in it?

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: A future. The only future I've got.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: That money wouldn't last forever. And then what? You'd be back in some other part of the rackets. Another Bobo Justus to slap you around and burn holes in your hands. This way, you've got to go the square route. You could send me a card when you're settled, I could maybe help out sometimes...

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: ) That's what it is, isn't it? Keep me down. Your turn to be in charge, have the power.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Just trying to help, Lilly.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Roy... What if I told you I wasn't really your mother? That we weren't related?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: There's nothing more to talk about.

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: I have to have that money, Roy. What do I have to do to get it?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Lilly, Jesus, what are you doing?

turns.speaker: LILLY
turns.text: Is there nothing I can do, Roy, nothing at --

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: NO!

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: You heard the shower, didn't you?

turns.speaker: MANAGER
turns.text: I don't care about that. This time, I gotta have the rent.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: Joe, I thought I was gonna be all right by now, I just need a little more --

turns.speaker: MANAGER
turns.text: It isn't the owner, Myra, it's my wife. She knows what's going on. This time, I gotta have the money.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: Joe, you know you'll --

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: Joe, could we talk it over? Do you want a drink?

turns.speaker: MANAGER
turns.text: My wife sent me here, Myra. For the money. She's waiting.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: I'll have it tonight. Nine o'clock? Ten?

turns.speaker: MANAGER
turns.text: This time...

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: We'll work something out, Joe.

turns.speaker: MINTZ
turns.text: I didn't teach you that.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: You taught me a lot. Then I invented.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Let me see how you did that one.

turns.speaker: MINTZ
turns.text: Scram. Go home.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: I can't. I just left home.

turns.speaker: MINTZ
turns.text: You're too young. You should be in school.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: I am in school.

turns.speaker: MINTZ
turns.text: Where's the five?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: In your other hand.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: Well, well. In a real hurry, are we?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Always, for you, baby.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: You aren't taking me for granted, are you?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Taking you for granite?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: That isn't granite. If that fell on me, it wouldn't hurt at all.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: Are you sure?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Let's find out.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: Roy?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Mm?

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: Look at me.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Oh, I am, baby, believe me.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: Roy? It this all we have?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: All? It ain't bad.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: No more than this?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: What are you talking abut, Myra? Marriage?

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: I didn't say that. You aren't marriage material.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Ow! Hey, what are you trying to do, throw me off my game?

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: No, baby. Come to Mama.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: You were bleeding inside, honey. Remember that bruise you had?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: You called the doctor, huh?

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: Well, no, Roy. Your mother found you.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Oh, yeah?  Thanks.  How long do they say I'm in here?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Her job.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: I want to know everything about you.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: You do. And once I'm out of here, I'll remind you of the best parts.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: I don't see why you're still here. You look healthy to me.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: I just do what the doctor says, babe.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: You're just comfortable, that's all. You don't even ask to go home. You just lie around, let your mama take care of you.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Mama!

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: Who else is paying for all this? You badmouth the woman all the time, but you sure do take the payoffs she gives you.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: I'll pay Lilly back, don't you worry about that.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: I don't like to come here, Roy. Every time I do, your mother comes in and makes remarks.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: That's just Lilly's way.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: And you never defend me. You're afraid of her.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Oh, don't be stupid.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: You're a mama's boy, if you want the truth.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: Get well soon.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Every day in every way.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: I'll see you when you get home.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: I don't see why we have to take the train.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Because it's comfortable.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: What if we want to drive somewhere while we're there?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: We'll rent a car.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: Big spender.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: You ain't seen nothin.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: See you soon.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: You were right, I had to get out of that hospital. Nothing wrong with me any more.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: I'll sign that affidavit.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Great to get away, take it easy. Next week, I'll get back to work.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: You already went back to work.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: I watched you. Working the tap on those soldier boys.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Working the what?

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: Oh, come on, Roy.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: The tap. What you do for a living.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: I'm a salesman.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: You're on the grift. Same as me.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Myra, I'm not following this.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: Roy, you're a short-con operator. And a good one, I think. Don't talk to me like I'm another square.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: You talk the lingo. What's your pitch?

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: The long end. Big con.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Nobody does that single-o.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: I was teamed ten years with the best in the business. Cole Langley.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: I've heard the name.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: It was beautiful. And getting better all the time.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Is that right?

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: It is, Roy! And now, right now, it's the perfect time, the best time since I've been in the game.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: He didn't think they were risks. He was so good, Roy, he could just play with the mark.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: And when he got serious?

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: He'd explain he had to have cash, so there wouldn't be any paper trail for the SEC. And a lot of cash, or it wasn't worth while. The least we ever took was forty thousand, and the most was one hundred eighty-five thousand dollars! From one sucker!

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: I thought these people were broke.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: No, no, Roy, just cash poor. They had savings accounts, stocks to sell, houses to mortgage. Sell their wife's jewelry. Oh, they had a lot of money, when they put their minds to it. Or when I put their minds to it. I stayed with them, that's the roper's job, made them get up every penny they could raise, turn it all over to Cole.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: And a month later, the sucker calls the cops and you're on the run.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: No no! He never calls the cops, not after we give him the blow-off.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Yeah? How?

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: Oh, Roy, it was great! We were rolling in dough, lived wherever we wanted, only pulled two or three scams a year.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: What happened to Cole?

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: He retired.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: Upstate.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Upstate where?

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: Atascadero.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: That's where they keep the criminally insane, isn't it?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: I just bet you are, too. And now you're trying to rope me.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: Join up with you! I watched you, Roy, I've been watching you, wondering if I should talk about this at all, or maybe just...

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Take a hike, you mean?

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: I need a partner, Roy. I need an inside man, and you're it. You could be as wonderful as Cole.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: I don't know, Myra, I never had partners. I never needed them.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: Not to take soldiers for a hundred bucks. But how about taking a bank president for a hundred grand?

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: Think about it. Okay?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: I still don't see why we have to have separate rooms. You expect your father to come through?

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: Separate bathrooms, darling. I will not lay out all my cosmetics for you to knock over.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Things a man isn't supposed to know.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: You don't mind, really, do you, Roy? It's been such a wonderful evening, I guess I just wore myself out.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Sure. I'm pretty tired myself.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: Open your door.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: What?  What for?

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: Open it and find out.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: You -- I don't know.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: ) If you could have seen your face when I told you good night! You looked so, so... Ah!

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Oh, come here.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: You were gone for a while.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: I went out to Delmar.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: ) The track? Did you run into Lilly?

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: I saw her.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: She didn't see you, in other words.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: I'm not trying to make trouble, Roy. It's just, she's always so nasty to me, I thought, who is she to be so high and mighty. I saw her out there, and I called a friend of mine in Baltimore, so now I know who she is.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: You must have some very knowledgeable friends.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: I'm well connected, Roy, Cole introduced me to a lot of people. Very valuable. Valuable for us.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Running your broker scam, you mean.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: You and me, Roy. What a team we'll make. We think alike; we get along together. Once or twice a year we take some slob, the rest of the time we live like this. You won't regret this, Roy.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Regret what? I didn't say I was coming aboard.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: But why not? I thought it was settled. What's holding you back?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Come on, Myra, don't talk business here. This is time out.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: You mean, it would be too tough to give me a turndown here. Easier on home grounds.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Yes or no. They're both easier at home. Okay?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: And hello to you, too.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: I called a fellow I know in Tulsa, the one who plays my chauffeur. There's a sucker there he says is made for us. And a boroker that just shut down, we can use their office, not change a thing! Now, I can scrape up ten grand without much trouble. That leaves fifteen or twenty for your end. We could start this weekend, get the sucker into position --

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Wait a minute! When did this happen, that we're partners?

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: The last I looked, we were just talking things over.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: But the setup's there. It's there now.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: I don't think I need it.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: You're too good for the small-time, Roy. Move up to where there's big dough to be made, and you don't have to stick your neck out every day.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Maybe I like it where I am.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Don't I get any say in this?

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: No! Because I --

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: That's what I say.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: What I say is, no. We don't do partners.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: For Christ's sake, why not?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Mostly, because you scare the shit out of me. I've seen people like you before, baby. Double-tough and sharp as they come, and you get what you want or else. But you don't make it work forever.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: Bullshit!

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: No; history. Sooner or later, the lightning hits. I don't want to be around when it hits you.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: What is it? What's going on?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: I'm happy the way I am.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: By God, it's your mother. It's Lilly.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: ) What?

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: Sure it is. That's why you act so funny around each other.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: Don't act so goddamned innocent! You and your own mother, gah! You like to go back where you been, huh?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: You watch that mouth.

turns.speaker: MYRA
turns.text: I'm wise to you, I should have seen it before, you rotten son of a bitch. How is it, huh? How do you like --

turns.speaker: PIERSON
turns.text: Roy Dillon?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: PIERSON
turns.text: Lieutenant Pierson, Phoenix police. I have a car here.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: PIERSON
turns.text: I realize this is a shock.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Well, mostly, I don't believe it.

turns.speaker: PIERSON
turns.text: That's natural.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: No. I mean, I don't believe it. Lilly is not a suicide. I know my mother, nothing would make her check out.

turns.speaker: PIERSON
turns.text: I'm sorry, it was her all right. Her gun, even.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Gun?

turns.speaker: PIERSON
turns.text: I grant you, it's a little odd, shoot yourself with a gun with a silencer on it, but it was hers, all right. It really is your mother, Mister Dillon.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: It may be Lilly, but it isn't suicide.

turns.speaker: PIERSON
turns.text: Do you have any particular reason to say that?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: My mother... Well, I guess it doesn't matter now. She worked for gamblers. She always knew they might turn on her some day.

turns.speaker: PIERSON
turns.text: A hit, you mean. Honestly, it doesn't have that feel to it, but I'll certainly consider the possibility. Thank you for telling me.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Not that it matters.  This is the morgue?

turns.speaker: PIERSON
turns.text: You up to it now?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Sure. Let's get it over.

turns.speaker: PIERSON
turns.text: One thing I have to caution you about. A gunshot wound...

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Yes, I know, I know.

turns.speaker: PIERSON
turns.text: Well, uh, you know, she ate the gun.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: PIERSON
turns.text: I'm sorry, that's an unfortunate phrase, it slipped out, I'm, to tell you the truth, Mr. Dillon, this isn't an everyday occurrence around here.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Ate the gun. Oh.

turns.speaker: PIERSON
turns.text: Someone who knows her well could still identify her, that's not the problem. It's just there's, uh, it's likely to be a shock.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Well, let's get the shock over with.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Not many laughs in this room, eh?

turns.speaker: PIERSON
turns.text: Not many.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Oh, Jesus.

turns.speaker: PIERSON
turns.text: No question, huh?

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: No, its -- Why did she--?

turns.speaker: PIERSON
turns.text: That's that, then.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Oh, yeah. That's that.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Mr. Simms.

turns.speaker: SIMMS
turns.text: Why yes, Mr. Dillon. Here's a potential new neighbor, looking at--

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Uh-huh. Mrs. Langtry may drop by.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Well, thank you. And thank them.

turns.speaker: SIMMS
turns.text: Sickness comes to us all, Mister Dillon.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: That's true, Mr. Simms.

turns.speaker: SIMMS
turns.text: We never know when and we never know why. We never know how. The only blessed thing we know is, it'll be at the most inconvenient and unexpected time. Just when you've got tickets to the World Series. And that's the way the permanent waves.

turns.speaker: ROY
turns.text: Well, I'm back now. I just wanted you to know. Gotta rush.

turns.speaker: SIMMS
turns.text: Happy to see you looking so good.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: No thanks, I'm not thirsty.

turns.speaker: BLAKE
turns.text: It's for your cigarette.  I prefer not to contaminate my crime scene with micropollutants.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Why am I here?

turns.speaker: BLAKE
turns.text: They said on the phone you were assigned to the Meyers case.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: With all due respect, detective, you can't go blaming every brutal murder in Illinois on Michael Meyers.

turns.speaker: BLAKE
turns.text: Pamela Whittington was a long time associate of Dr. Loomis.  Her home office was ransacked.  It was chock full of Loomis' files on Meyers.  It'd say that makes Meyers a suspect, wouldn't you?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Well, when you put it that way.

turns.speaker: BLAKE
turns.text: Right.  So why don't we get on with this investigation?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: I like a woman who takes control.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: One set of muddy shoe prints.

turns.speaker: BLAKE
turns.text: That don't match either of the victim's.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Where, judging by the looks of the finger and palm prints, she struggles to open the window before banging on it like hell.

turns.speaker: BLAKE
turns.text: Unable to escape, she turns and attacks the killer, but doesn't connect.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: No blood on the knife.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: The killer knocks the knife out of her hand with the wrought-iron poker.

turns.speaker: BLAKE
turns.text: Broken blood vessels on her right forearm.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: As which point she drops to her knees in pain...

turns.speaker: BLAKE
turns.text: Explaining the low height of the blood splatter on the curtains...

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Impressive, Blake.  Where'd you learn how to do that?

turns.speaker: BLAKE
turns.text: Girl scouts.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Carter.

turns.speaker: BLAKE
turns.text: It's Blake.  Meet me at Grand View.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: BLAKE
turns.text: The cemetery...

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Yeah, alright... I'll be there in ten.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: You take all your dates here. Blake?

turns.speaker: BLAKE
turns.text: Only the real stiffs.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: I can be real stiff.

turns.speaker: BLAKE
turns.text: Charming.

turns.speaker: BLAKE
turns.text: That's it?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Care to join me?

turns.speaker: BLAKE
turns.text: Come on, Carter.  You know it's Michael.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: What do you want me to do, put out an A.P.B. on a man in overalls wearing a white mask dragging a headstone?

turns.speaker: BLAKE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Sweet dreams, Blake.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Carter.

turns.speaker: BLAKE
turns.text: It's Blake.  How do you feel about Wisconsin?

turns.speaker: BLAKE
turns.text: We're sorry to startle you, Miss Tate.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: The door was open, so we let ourselves in.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Detective Carter from the Haddonfield P.D.

turns.speaker: BLAKE
turns.text: Toni Blake from Langley P.D.
